plugins.name: Logger
plugins.description:
Logger is a Figma plugin designed to help users log changes made to pages and frames within their Figma projects. The plugin provides an easy-to-use interface with two tabs: "Page log" and "Frame log".


Features

Page Log Tab:

  1. A text area box with the placeholder "Describe the change" where users can enter the change made to the page (mandatory field).
  2. A smaller text box with the placeholder "Change requested by" where users can enter the name of the person who requested the change (optional field).
  3. A "Log change" button that is enabled only when the mandatory fields are filled.

Frame Log Tab:

  1. A drop-down menu with the default value "Select frame" that shows the list of frames on the current page. Users can also select a frame directly on the page, and the frame name will be populated in the drop-down (mandatory field).
  2. A text area box with the placeholder "Describe the change" where users can enter the change made to the frame (mandatory field).
  3. A smaller text box with the placeholder "Change requested by" where users can enter the name of the person who requested the change (optional field).
  4. A "Log change" button that is enabled only when the mandatory fields are filled.


Usage Instructions

Page Log:

  1. Navigate to the "Page log" tab.
  2. Enter the description of the change in the "Describe the change" text area.
  3. (Optional) Enter the name of the person who requested the change in the "Change requested by" text box.
  4. Click the "Log change" button (enabled only when the mandatory fields are filled).

Frame Log:

  1. Navigate to the "Frame log" tab.
  2. Select a frame from the "Select frame" drop-down menu or directly select a frame on the page.
  3. Enter the description of the change in the "Describe the change" text area.
  4. (Optional) Enter the name of the person who requested the change in the "Change requested by" text box.
  5. Click the "Log change" button (enabled only when the mandatory fields are filled).


Logic

Page Log:

  1. When the user clicks the "Log change" button, the plugin checks if there is a page named "Change log" in Figma. If not, it creates one.
  2. The plugin then creates a text field with the name of the page for which the log is created within the "Change log" page and adds the following values: Date and time of the log, User's name requesting the change, Change description
  3. If the page and text already exist, the plugin appends the new values to the existing text.

Frame Log:

  1. When the user clicks the "Log change" button, the plugin checks if there is a text field on the frame with the name "Frame log". If not, it creates the text field within the selected frame (top left corner) and adds the following values:
  2. Date and time of the log
  3. User's name requesting the change
  4. Change description
  5. If the text field already exists, the plugin appends the new values to the existing text within the frame.


Conclusion

Logger is a powerful plugin for tracking changes in Figma projects, making it easier to manage and document modifications to pages and frames. With its intuitive interface and robust logging capabilities, Logger is an essential plugin for any Figma user.
plugins.tagline: A simple native plugin helping designers log their changes both at page as well as frame level.

plugins.name: Tablify
plugins.description:
Tablify is a powerful and flexible plugin that turns structured data into clean, styled tables directly in your Figma files. Whether youâ€™re working with CSVs, Google Sheets, Excel files, or even Word documents, Tablify makes it effortless to visualize your data with consistency and control.


Features


Multiple Input Formats


  1. Upload from CSV, TSV, Excel (.xlsx/.xls), Word (.docx), PDF, HTML, XML, ODS, ODT
  2. Supports Google Sheets via public URL â€” just paste the link, choose a sheet, and youâ€™re ready to go
  3. Drag & drop supported for local files


Intelligent Parsing


  1. Detects and handles multiple tables per document (e.g. Excel sheets or Word tables)
  2. Automatically cleans and parses content for structured layout
  3. Handles complex table structures, colspans, and headers


Design-Ready Tables


  1. Generates clean, structured Figma components
  2. Supports auto layout or fixed layout styles
  3. Responsive to Figma color variables, padding, radius, fonts, and more


Customization Options


  1. Auto Layout
  2. Header Row
  3. Style Variables (automatically created and bound)
  4. Automatically generates reusable tokens for colors, sizes, and text styles


Perfect for


  1. UI and product designers
  2. Dashboards, admin panels, data-heavy UIs
  3. Rapid prototyping with live spreadsheet content
  4. Importing structured data into Figma layouts with no manual copying


Why Tablify?


Unlike basic table creators, Tablify focuses on precision, flexibility, and deep Figma integration. Itâ€™s built for speed and scale â€” helping you go from spreadsheet to structured layout in seconds.

plugins.name: Flow Linker
plugins.description:
In large-scale design projects, prototyping every screen-to-screen interaction isnâ€™t always practical. With dozens or even hundreds of screens, building interactive flows becomes time-consuming and sometimes infeasible, especially when deadlines are tight or priorities shift.


Yet developers and stakeholders still need clarity. They rely on understanding how different screens connect, what the logical flow of a user journey looks like, and where transitions happen even without full prototypes.


Thatâ€™s where Flow Link comes in.


Rather than investing hours in building out detailed prototypes, Flow Link lets you visually map out interactions using clean, orthogonal connectors. These lines donâ€™t just show flowâ€”theyâ€™re configurable, styled, navigable, and reusable. And with frame linking, viewers can even jump directly to connected screens, making your Figma file interactive in structure, even without full prototyping.


Flow Link fills the gap between rapid design iteration and clear developer handoff making complex projects more navigable, understandable, and scalable.
plugins.tagline: Your Figma Flow, Made Effortless.

Step 1: Enter a base color in the Accent section to generate a palette.

Step 2: Copy the accent scale generated below.

Step 3: Copy the CSS code from:

.root, .light, .light-theme { ... }

Step 4: Repeat Steps 1â€“3 for the Dark Theme.

Step 5: Create a collection in Figma with two modes named exactly: Light Mode, Dark Mode (Case-sensitive)

Step 6: Paste the Light and Dark theme CSS into their respective input fields in the plugin.

Step 7: Click the "Create Variables" button.

Step 8: Edit variable names as needed in Figma.
plugins.tagline: Copy Radix CSS code and paste it here to instantly add your custom palette variables to the file.

plugins.name: Bulk Certificate Generator / Generador Masivo de Certificados
plugins.description:
How does this plugin work?


Users can automate the creation of personalized certificates inside Figma, avoiding the manual copy-pasting of required data.



Step-by-step: How to use the plugin


1 - Create the base design in Figma

  1. Design a certificate inside a Frame or Component.
  2. Use text layers named like #NAME, #COURSE, #DATE, etc.
  3. These names will be automatically replaced with data from the Sheet.


2 â€“ Prepare the Google Sheet

  1. Create a public Google Sheet.
  2. In the first row, write the field names: NAME, COURSE, DATE, ID, etc.
  3. Fill the rows with each personâ€™s data.
  4. Make sure the document is public (set to â€œAnyone with the link can viewâ€).


3 â€“ Select your design in Figma

  1. Select the Frame or Component containing your base design.
  2. Only one selection is allowed when running the plugin.


4 â€“ Open the plugin

  1. Run the plugin from the Figma menu.
  2. Paste the Google Sheet link.
  3. Enter the sheet name (e.g., Students).
  4. Toggle the â€œShow IDâ€ option on or off if you want to hide it.


5 â€“ Preview (optional)

  1. Click â€œPreviewâ€ to generate just one sample certificate.


6 â€“ Generate certificates

  1. Click â€œGenerate.â€
  2. The plugin will clone your base design, replace the fields, and automatically arrange the certificates on the Figma page.


7 - Have fun!
plugins.tagline: DiseÃ±Ã¡ uno, generÃ¡ cientos. Certificados personalizados en Figma desde un Google Sheet.

plugins.name: Zeytal Variables Extractor
plugins.description:
Zeytal helps developers extract and optimize SVGs, transform Figma styles and variables, and generate TailwindCSS config files effortlessly.


This plugin helps Zeytal users leverage their Figma variables.


Zeytal Features

  1. Extract and optimize SVGs
  2. Extract and convert Figma variables to .ts, .js, .json, .css, .scss, .sass, and .less files
  3. Extract and convert Figma styles to .ts, .js, .json, .css, .scss, .sass, and .less files
  4. Convert Figma styles and variables to TailwindCSS v4 config files.


This Plugin

This plugin helps Figma users prepare their Figma files for Figma variables extraction and code generation.


How it works :

  1. Start the plugin.
  2. Click on one button to export your Figma variables to Zeytal
  3. Use Zeytal CLI to generate your code and config files


Everything is explained in detail in Zeytal documentation.

plugins.name: ä¸€é”®ç¿»è¯‘å…ƒç´  Quick Translate
plugins.description:
Introduction

Quick Translate is a Figma plugin designed to help you instantly translate selected text elements into different languages with just one click. Save time and improve your workflow by translating text directly within your design files.


Function Description

  1. Translate selected text elements into a specified target language.
  2. Supports multiple languages and automatic translation of all text layers in a Figma selection.
  3. Easy-to-use interface to select languages and apply translations quickly.
  4. Ideal for designers working on multilingual projects or collaborating with global teams.


How to Use

  1. Select one or more text elements in your Figma file.
  2. Open the plugin from the "Plugins" menu.
  3. Choose the target language for translation.
  4. Click the "Translate" button, and the selected text will be replaced with the translated version.


Notes

  1. Ensure your Figma selection includes text elements, as the plugin only works with text layers.
  2. The translation may vary depending on the accuracy of the API and the language selected.
  3. For optimal results, select only relevant text elements to avoid unnecessary API calls.

plugins.tagline: Quick Translate: Instant Translation for Figma Elements

137614.name: ä¸€é”®ç¿»è¯‘å…ƒç´  Quick Translate
137614.description:
Introduction

Quick Translate is a Figma plugin designed to help you instantly translate selected text elements into different languages with just one click. Save time and improve your workflow by translating text directly within your design files.


Function Description

  1. Translate selected text elements into a specified target language.
  2. Supports multiple languages and automatic translation of all text layers in a Figma selection.
  3. Easy-to-use interface to select languages and apply translations quickly.
  4. Ideal for designers working on multilingual projects or collaborating with global teams.


How to Use

  1. Select one or more text elements in your Figma file.
  2. Open the plugin from the "Plugins" menu.
  3. Choose the target language for translation.
  4. Click the "Translate" button, and the selected text will be replaced with the translated version.


Notes

  1. Ensure your Figma selection includes text elements, as the plugin only works with text layers.
  2. The translation may vary depending on the accuracy of the API and the language selected.
  3. For optimal results, select only relevant text elements to avoid unnecessary API calls.

plugins.description:
Introduction

This plugin is designed to help users export detailed JSON data of selected nodes, including auto layout information, Frame nesting relationships, text properties, and more. With this plugin, users can easily retrieve structured data from design elements, facilitating data analysis, secondary development, or documentation.


åŠŸèƒ½

  1. Export complete JSON data of selected nodes, including properties like type, name, size, position, fills, strokes, and more.
  2. Support exporting text content, font name, font size, and other properties of text nodes.
  3. Support nested export of nodes such as Frame, Group, Component, and Instance, preserving the full hierarchical structure.
  4. Complete export of auto layout information, including layout mode, primary and secondary axis alignment, padding, and spacing.
  5. Safely serialized JSON data export ensures compatibility and completeness.


Usage Instructions

  1. Select one or more nodes from which you want to export data.
  2. Click the export button in the plugin, and the plugin will automatically extract all relevant information from the selected nodes and generate JSON data.
  3. The exported JSON data will be displayed in the plugin interface, allowing users to copy or download it for further use.


Notes

  1. This plugin currently supports exporting properties of common node types such as Frame.
  2. Ensure that the selected node types are supported by the plugin; otherwise, related data might not be exportable.
  3. If errors occur during the export process, check whether the nodes contain excessive nesting or complex properties. Simplify the structure if needed and try again.

plugins.name: WEMS for Figma
plugins.description:
WEMS is a powerful platform that transforms your Figma prototypes into fully functional websites or mobile app view in just a few clicks. Designed for modern creators and product teams, WEMS allows you to:


  1. Convert Figma designs into responsive websites or mobile app view
  2. Optimize pages with built-in SEO tools for website
  3. Add translations for multilingual support
  4. Integrate Lottie and Rive animations
  5. Embed MP4 or other embeddable videos (Youtube, Facebook, Vimeo, Twitch etc.)
  6. Support forms with inputs and data send to endpoint
  7. Integrate payment forms or buttons with own products
  8. Connect a custom domain
  9. Run A/B tests to experiment and improve
  10. Track performance with built-in analytics


With WEMS, you can go from design to deployment in record time â€” no coding required
